importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article highlights a critical update on food aid to Gaza, indicating ongoing humanitarian challenges despite a ceasefire.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current timeframe reflects the immediate humanitarian situation in Gaza following the ceasefire, with urgent needs for expanded food deliveries and cross-border access.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes arriving daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently open, severely limiting aid flow.
The WFP operates 26 food distribution points in Gaza, up from five, but still far short of the planned 145 distribution points.
The ceasefire brokered by US President Donald Trump is seen as vital for saving lives and preventing famine in northern Gaza.
Humanitarian aid has reached northern Gaza via the south, but not in sufficient volume to meet nutritional needs of children and pregnant women.
Many Palestinians are storing food due to fears about the stability of the ceasefire and future conflict.
The Rafah border crossing remains closed until Hamas hands over the bodies of deceased captives, which limits access to southern and Egyptian-linked aid routes.
Hamas has pledged to return 28 captives’ bodies and has already delivered 13, with two more to be handed over as of Tuesday.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global humanitarian organization that delivers food aid to people in crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article, reporting on food supply levels and urging more open border crossings to meet Gaza’s needs.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two currently open crossings, it allows food and aid to enter Gaza, but its limited operation restricts aid distribution.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kerem Shalom)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second operational crossing, it is essential for humanitarian aid flow but remains insufficient for meeting Gaza’s food needs.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Currently closed, its closure restricts humanitarian access and deepens the food crisis in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been permitted to use this route to deliver food, limiting access to northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group with control over Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas has agreed to return the bodies of Israeli captives, which is a condition for reopening the Rafah crossing and affecting humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has stated that the Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas hands over captives’ remains, directly impacting aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 20-point plan for ending the war includes full aid to Gaza, and his ceasefire brokered the current humanitarian situation.

namedEntities.name: US President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The same entity as above, referred to in context of the ceasefire and aid plan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role as broker of the ceasefire and advocate for full aid delivery makes him central to the narrative of aid access.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically low, with only 750 metric tonnes of food entering daily—far below the target of 2,000 tonnes—due to only two border crossings being open. Despite a ceasefire brokered by US President Donald Trump, access remains severely restricted, especially in northern Gaza where aid has not reached in large convoys. The WFP operates 26 distribution points, still far short of the planned 145, and many Palestinians are storing food due to fears of renewed conflict. The Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas delivers the bodies of deceased captives, and humanitarian access is limited by political and military conditions. The article emphasizes the urgent need for more open crossings and sustained political agreements to prevent famine.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
